Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Why poison frogs don't poison themselves: phylogenetic origins and consequences of autoresistance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Poison frogs (family Dendrobatidae) are well known for their bright colors and for the toxins (alkaloids) contained in their skin. In fact, some of the most powerful natural toxins known are found in dendrobatid frogs. Because these toxins interfere with the function of ion channels (proteins in cell membranes that control muscle contraction and sensory systems), predators exposed to poison frog alkaloids may experience numbness, slowed muscle response, or even respiratory failure at high doses. Predators of poison frogs learn to associate the frog's bright color with distastefulness and toxicity, and then avoid them as prey items.

How is that poison frogs are not poisoned by their own toxins, and how could such a complex system evolve? One hypothesis is that genetic changes in ion channels within poison frogs prevent the adverse effects of alkaloids and thus prevent self-toxicity, and that this pre-adaptation enabled the evolution of the overall predatory defense system. This project will utilize new methods of DNA analysis and physiological tests of ion channel function in toxic and non-toxic poison frogs to reveal the evolutionary basis of toxin resistance in this group. In a broader context, this research will contribute to understanding the general effects of toxins and how resistance to these toxins can evolve. It will also strengthen international collaborations between scientists in Ecuador and the United States, and train several students in field and laboratory work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Many animals use chemicals to defend themselves from predators, including bumblebees, butterflies, coral snakes, frogs, and skunks. However, these animals face a difficult challenge: how can they be toxic but avoid poisoning themselves? The evolution of chemical defenses is complicated and often spurs numerous physiological changes as an organism adapts to high levels of toxin exposure. Early in this process, the organism must evolve resistance to self-intoxication, or autoresistance. This trait then allows an organism to develop higher levels of chemical defenses without harming itself. Our study aimed to investigate how poison frogs, a classic example of a chemically defended animal, resist their own defenses, and how the ability to resist auto-intoxication has influenced the evolution of chemical defenses in this group.

Poison frogs acquire and accumulate alkaloids from small arthropods (mostly ants and mites) in their diet. These chemicals target specific proteins in the nervous system that control the flow of information within the brain and in sensory systems that the frogs use to perceive their environment. At high enough concentrations, these chemicals can be lethal; at low concentrations, they are distasteful. In either case, they can turn away predators from a potential tasty snack. We found that poison frogs resist their toxins through simple genetic changes in the target proteins of their toxins. Essentially, they are genetically modified to be insensitive to their own toxins. In most cases, the ability to resist toxins evolved at the same time as the ability to acquire toxins (Tarvin et al. 2016; Tarvin et al. 2017); this indicates that these traits are interconnected and evolve together.

Autoresistance is really just the first step to evolving chemical defenses. How do organisms accumulate and transport toxins? How and why do many toxic organisms become brightly colored? How can poison frogs wield more than 800 different types of chemicals? These questions led us to identify more than 100 genes potentially evolved in the origin of this complex trait. Funds from this grant were used to design and purchase custom lab reagents for sequencing these genes from more than 50 species of poison frogs, and the lab work is in progress. Once we receive our data, we expect to be able to identify hundreds of genetic changes associated with the transition from non-defended to defended, which will guide future experimental work. This genetic information will tell the evolutionary history of poison frogs and help us understand how toxicity evolves.

This project highlights the emergence of integrative biology and functional genomics as a primary method for understanding protein evolution. Moreover, our research characterizes unique aspects of proteins that are integral to the nervous system, and thus has implications for drug development and targeted gene therapy. Revealing mechanisms of toxin resistance in poison frogs can also help us combat pesticide resistance in insects, a billion-dollar agroeconomic issue. Finally, poison frogs have shown us how animals can adapt over millennia to co-exist with toxins; they may hold the secret to dealing with long-term exposure to toxins in humans or in animals at risk of extinction.

 

Broader Impacts. During the tenure of this grant, we trained one high school, four undergraduate and many graduate students (minority and non-minority, from the USA and from Ecuador) in aspects of fieldwork, lab work, and/or bioinformatics. Tarvin created and taught two different courses in bioinformatics that are freely available online (http://ccbbatut.github.io/Biocomputing_Spring2016/ and https://rdtarvin.github.io/RADseq_Quito_2017/). Our research is highly collaborative and involves institutions in the USA, Canada, Ecuador, Colombia, and Brazil, including three different labs within the University of Texas at Austin. Results have been disseminated at four invited University seminars, seven academic conferences, three news interviews, and three public outreach events. Hundreds of genetic samples have been deposited in museums in Ecuador and Colombia and dozens of sequences have been deposited into the publicly available NCBI GenBank database.

 

Resulting publications:

Tarvin, RD, CM Borghese, W Sachs, JC Santos, L Yu, LA O'Connell, DC Cannatella, RA Harris, and HH Zakon. 2017. Interacting amino acid replacements allow poison frogs to evolve epibatidine resistance. Science 357: 1261-1266.

Tarvin, RD, E Powell, JC Santos, SR Ron, and DC Cannatella. 2017. The birth of aposematism: High phenotypic divergence and low genetic diversity in a young clade of poison frogs. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution 109: 283–295. (not directly supported by NSF DEB 1404409)

Tarvin, RD, JC Santos, LA O'Connell, HH Zakon, and DC Cannatella. 2016. Convergent substitutions in sodium channel suggest multiple origins of toxin resistance in poison frogs. Molecular Biology and Evolution 33: 1068–1081.

Santos, JC, RD Tarvin, and LA O'Connell. 2016. A review of chemical defense in poison frogs (Dendrobatidae): Ecology, pharmacokinetics and autoresistance. In: Schulte, BA, TE Goodwin, MH Ferkin, Eds. Chemical Signals in Vertebrates 13. Switzerland: Springer International Publishing. p. 305-337.
